translated: Treatise on Revealing Consciousness, 1 fascicle, from the Treatise on No-characteristics
Translated by ParamÄrtha Tripiá¹­aka
The three realms are only consciousness. What is it? The three realms have two kinds of
consciousness:
First, revealing consciousness; second, discriminating consciousness.
Revealing consciousness is the fundamental consciousness. This fundamental consciousness transforms into the five sense objects, the four elements, and so forth.
What is discriminating consciousness?

It is the mental consciousness. Within revealing consciousness, it discriminates and creates humans, gods, long, short, large, small, male, female, trees, vines, and various things, and discriminates all phenomena.
This aggregate of consciousness discriminates the dharma realm and is called discriminating consciousness.
It is like how, relying on the color of a mirror, the color of a reflection arises. In the same way, depending on revealing consciousness, discriminating consciousness arises.
When this discrimination arises, it establishes the power of perfuming in the Älaya consciousness. By the power of this perfuming, the fundamental consciousness will be able to arise in the future;
Depending on this future revealing consciousness, the future discriminating consciousness will be able to arise.
For this reason, birth and death have no beginning or end.
In order to illustrate this meaning, the Buddha spoke a verse in the Explanation of the Knots Sutra:
Manifest consciousness gives rise to discrimination, discrimination gives rise to perfuming,
Perfuming gives rise to manifest consciousness, thus the wheel of birth and death turns.
As for what is called perfuming, the first is clinging to the discriminated nature, and the second is contemplating and cultivating the true nature.
For these two meanings, it is called perfuming.
The first perfuming increases the Älaya consciousness.
When the Älaya consciousness is increased, it is fully capable of giving rise to the consciousnesses of the six destinies that experience birth. For this reason, birth and death are complete.
The second perfuming is called contemplating and cultivating the true nature. This perfuming can eliminate clinging to the discriminated nature.
Because the first perfuming is damaged, the Älaya consciousness is also damaged.
When the Älaya consciousness is damaged, the consciousness that receives birth is also damaged.
Because the Älaya consciousness is able to give rise to the three realms, by being damaged, one attains the turning of the three realms.
The meaning of this turning of the basis is endowed with five aspects, as explained in the chapter on the characteristics of cessation.
The manifestation of consciousness is of nine kinds:

1. Body consciousness, 2. object consciousness, 3. function consciousness, 4. world consciousness, 5. vessel consciousness, 6. number consciousness, 7. four kinds of verbal consciousness, 8. self and other different consciousness, 9. good and evil birth and death consciousness.
Next, consciousness is distinguished as being of two kinds:
1. Consciousness of the embodied one, 2. consciousness of the experiencer.
Among the first nine consciousnesses, the first, body consciousness, means transforming and appearing as a body, and therefore consciousness is called body consciousness.
What is meant by like is that the appearance of the grasped body is like a body, but it is not real, and therefore it is called like a body.
This consciousness is able to create a semblance of a body, and is called body consciousness, which is the five sense organs.
The remaining eight kinds of consciousnesses, such as the consciousness of objects, are also like this, which is the meaning of consciousness-only.
As for the consciousness of the body, there are five kinds, namely the eye faculty realm and so forth, which are called the consciousness of the body, and they are all the five faculties.
The second, the consciousness of objects, has six kinds, from the form realm up to the object of consciousness, all of which are called the consciousness that should be experienced.
The third, the consciousness of function, has six kinds, from the eye consciousness realm and so forth, which are the six consciousnesses.
The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra calls it the consciousness of correct experience.
The fourth, the consciousness of time, has three kinds, namely the three times: past, future, and present.
Moreover, it is called time because the continuity of birth and death is uninterrupted.
The fifth, the consciousness of the container, is called the consciousness of place in the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra.
In brief, it is the container world, namely the external four great elements and five sense objects. In detail, it includes the ten directions and the three realms and so forth.
The sixth, the consciousness of number, is counting and measuring.
The seventh is the four kinds of verbal consciousness, namely seeing, hearing, knowing, and perceiving.
All verbal expressions do not go beyond these four. If one does not speak of seeing, one speaks of hearing;
Knowing and perceiving are also like this.
The eighth is the consciousness of self and other differences, referring to the different bases and the six destinies.
The bases refer to the body, and the bodies of the six destinies are the consciousnesses of self and other differences.
The ninth is the consciousness of good and evil destinies and birth and death. All birth and death do not leave the two paths. The good are humans and gods, and the evil are the four destinies.
These good and evil paths do not leave birth and death, because birth and death arise and cease without stopping.
Moreover, there is the consciousness of one who has a body, covered by the view of self.
This consciousness is covered by the view of self and craving, so it experiences birth in the six destinies.

This consciousness is the body of birth and death. If there is this consciousness, there is the consciousness of the body. If this consciousness is exhausted, then the body of birth and death is exhausted.
I see that the birth of the view of self gives rise to all the afflictions of flesh, and the birth of craving gives rise to all the afflictions of skin, thus there is the body of birth and death.
If one is free from craving and the view of self, then there are no afflictions of skin and flesh.
If there are no afflictions of skin and flesh, then there is no body of the three realms, thus the body consciousness experiences birth and death.
Second, the consciousness of the recipient, which is called the consciousness of the recipient, is the three kinds of mental consciousness:
First, the Älaya consciousness, which is the subtle level of mental consciousness, always experiences the results of karma, is neither good nor evil, but is simply indeterminate;
Second, the manas consciousness, which is the middling level of mental consciousness, only experiences the results of karma for ordinary beings;
Third, the constantly manifest mental consciousness, which is the coarse level of mental consciousness, experiences the results of the three natures of good, evil, and indeterminate.
The five consciousnesses are also like this.
These three levels of mental consciousness are all able to experience the results of karma.
But now, based on the rise and fall, it is called the Älaya consciousness as the consciousness of the recipient.

Moreover, the Älaya consciousness is the place where ordinary beings conceive of a self. The ÄdÄna consciousness grasps the Älaya consciousness as the object of self, and the grasper is precisely the ÄdÄna consciousness.
The seven consciousnesses are the substance of the view of self, therefore discriminating consciousness is of two kinds:
one is the consciousness of the body, and the other is the consciousness of the possessor of the body, collectively called the root of mind.

The fundamentally defiled root is precisely the ÄdÄna consciousness, and the second condition is the substance of the root of mind, which takes the fundamental consciousness as the object of self. It clarifies the characteristics of the consciousnesses by revealing their objects. It shows that there are nine kinds of consciousnesses.
As explained above, consciousness only refers to the Älaya. If it is discriminating consciousness, it is the ÄdÄna and mental consciousnesses.
The ÄdÄna discriminates the self, while the mental consciousness discriminates myriad dharmas.
The mental consciousness has three kinds of discrimination, while the five consciousnesses only have the discrimination of self-nature.
There are four kinds of perfuming:
one is forbearance, two is name, three is characteristic, and four is the supreme worldly dharmas.
There are two kinds of forbearance:
one is extensive, and the other is concise.
All sentient beings are deluded about the true nature. Now, in cultivation, one first performs extensive contemplation and then concise contemplation to enter the truth.
What is meant by extensive is contemplating the four truths. Suffering and accumulation are the mundane truth of ordinary beings, while cessation and path are the true truth of sages.
Each has nine kinds. Contemplating the nine aspects of suffering is the three realms each having three periods of time to form nine.
Moreover, the desire realm has one existence, the form realm has four existences, and the formless realm has four existences, thus making nine kinds.
The nine aspects of the truth of accumulation are the nine bonds. Eliminating these nine bonds is the nine truths of cessation.
The nine aspects of the truth of the path are the nine successive samÄdhis, which are the nine successive concentrations.

Next, concise contemplation. First, contemplating the truth of suffering as eight kinds is contemplating the four elements and the four names. The four elements are the aggregate of form, and the four names are the four aggregates, making eight kinds.
The truth of suffering and accumulation having eight is the eight perversions contradicting the eightfold noble path.
The eight kinds of truth of cessation are that the cessation of the eight kinds of wrong is called the eight kinds of cessation.
The eight kinds of truth of the path are taking the cultivation of the eightfold noble path as the truth of the path.
Next, briefly contemplating suffering as seven kinds, the six destinies and the intermediate state.
The seven kinds of accumulation are the seven kinds of defilements.

The seven kinds of defilements are greed, hatred, delusion, pride, doubt, views, and the desire of the desire realm is called the defilement of desire, the form and formless realms are called the defilement of existence, combined into seven kinds of defilements. The cessation of the seven kinds of defilements is called the seven kinds of cessation.
The seven kinds of truth of the path are the seven factors of enlightenment.
Next, briefly contemplating suffering as six kinds, namely the six internal sense bases.
The six kinds of accumulation are the six kinds of craving, which are the six kinds of greed arising from the six sense objects.
The cessation of the six kinds of greed is the six kinds of cessation.
The six kinds of path are the six kinds of realms of deliverance:

First, the realm of cultivating loving-kindness to transcend killing others and anger, second, the realm of cultivating compassion to transcend oppression and anger, third, the realm of cultivating joy to transcend jealousy and anger, fourth, the realm of cultivating equanimity to transcend lust, fifth, the realm of cultivating mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation to transcend the defilements of thoughts and contemplations, and sixth, the realm of cultivating non-self to transcend the delusion of ignorance.
Cultivating these six kinds is called the realm of transcendence.
Next, briefly contemplating suffering as five, namely the five aggregates.
Accumulation as five, namely the five hindrances.
Extinguishing these five hindrances as five kinds of cessation.
The five paths are the five faculties and the five powers, etc.
Next, briefly contemplating suffering as four kinds, namely the four establishments of mindfulness: body, feelings, mind, and dharmas.
Accumulation as four is the four clingings, which are also the four streams.
The four clingings are simply craving, which has four kinds of craving, which are the four kinds of clinging:
first, clinging to desire, second, clinging to views, third, clinging to precepts, and fourth, clinging to self-assertion.

The grasping of self-doctrine refers to grasping the internal five aggregates and craving the inner dharmas of the eight concentrations and formless attainments, which is called the grasping of self-doctrine.
Within this, grasping is called the grasping of self-doctrine.
If one craves for the objects of the desire realm, it is called external dharmas, and is called the grasping of desire.

The grasping of desire is for sentient beings with the view of annihilation, while the grasping of self-doctrine is for sentient beings with the view of permanence. These two dharmas give rise to the views of grasping at false views and grasping at precepts and practices.
Grasping at the view of permanence arises based on principles.
These four graspings are the provisions for receiving.
It is explained that there are three kinds of craving for receiving:
First, the craving for separation, which refers to all sentient beings in the three evil paths.
Second, the craving for attainment, which refers to humans, celestials, up to the three formless [realms];
Third, the craving for abiding, which refers to the neither perception nor non-perception [heaven] considering it to be nirvana.
Just as the four kinds of grasping are called the truth of accumulation,
The cessation of the four graspings is called the four truths of cessation.
The four truths of the path refer to the four establishments of mindfulness, which are the four kinds of prajÃ±Ä:

Contemplating the body penetrates the truth of suffering, contemplating feelings penetrates the truth of accumulation, contemplating the mind penetrates the truth of cessation, and contemplating dharmas penetrates the truth of the path.

Contemplating the body as coarse, contemplating the coarse body of the three realms as suffering, contemplating the body of the desire realm as suffering from cold, heat, etc., contemplating the body of the form realm as suffering in the four deportments, and contemplating the mind of the formless realm as suffering from moment-to-moment impermanence.

Contemplating feelings and penetrating the truth of accumulation means that all the greed and love of sentient beings are conditioned by feelings, and if there were no feelings, greed would not arise. Therefore, by contemplating feelings, one penetrates the truth of accumulation.

If contemplating the mind and penetrating the truth of cessation means that all sentient beings establish the view of self in the mind, therefore sentient beings cling to the view of self and do not believe in cessation. It is precisely because the aggregate consciousness clings to the store consciousness as being one and permanent that the essence of self is not extinguished.
Contemplating the mind as not being the self, one thus believes in cessation and abandons the view of self.
Contemplating the two kinds of no-self of person and dharmas, one thus contemplates the mind and penetrates the truth of cessation.
As for contemplating the Dharma and penetrating the truth of the path, there are two kinds of Dharma:
One is the pure aspect, and the other is the impure aspect.
Contemplating the impure aspect is suffering and its causes, and the pure Dharma is cessation and the path.
Moreover, the impure aspect is all afflictions, and the pure aspect is all the methods of practice, so one should penetrate the truth of the path.
Next, briefly contemplating suffering in three ways is contemplating the three realms as suffering:
Contemplating the desire realm as the suffering of suffering;ğŸ”½Contemplating the form realm as the suffering of change, because when the joy changes, it is suffering;
Contemplating the formless realm as the suffering of formations, because in the three times of birth, abiding, and change, there is suffering.
But sentient beings have two paths: the evil path is suffering, and the good path is happiness. Abandoning these two extremes is called nirvana.
This mind has activity and movement, and therefore it is impermanent and suffering.
As for the three kinds of causes, they are the three poisons, and there are also three kinds:
The view of self, attachment to precepts, and doubt.
The view of self means that sentient beings, attached to the view of self, grasp at permanence, bliss, self, and purity, and therefore abide in birth and death, not cultivating the supramundane path.
Adherence to rules and rituals means being unwilling to cultivate the correct path.
Doubt means being doubtful and indecisive.
The truth of cessation extinguishes these three kinds of afflictions, which are then the three cessations.
The three of the path refer to precepts, concentration, and wisdom.
Next, briefly contemplating suffering as two, namely body and mind;
It is also called name-and-form.
The two of accumulation in the twelve links of dependent arising refer to ignorance and craving.
Extinguishing these two kinds is the two kinds of cessation.
The two of the truth of the path refer to concentration and wisdom.
Next, briefly contemplating suffering as one, namely impermanence is suffering.
Accumulation refers to incorrect thought.
Extinguishing this thought is cessation.
The path refers to mindfulness of the body, which is the overall contemplation of the four establishments of mindfulness called mindfulness of the body.
Moreover, if one contemplates the truth of the path, it is the truth of the path. If one contemplates wrongly, it is the truth of the accumulation. One wishes to make true wisdom clear.
One contemplates suffering in two ways, extensive and brief. One makes all dharmas into nine parts up to one part. The other three truths are also like this.
The four kinds of expedient means of verbal and conceptual perfuming.
Verbal perfuming means from the stage of patience up to the stage of the nature of dharmas.
What is called a stage is called the object and the realm is the stage.
Conceptual perfuming means from characteristics up to the first stage of attaining all cultivated dharmas.
The stage of attaining all cultivated dharmas means from the lower stage up to the superior characteristics, the first stage is the realm.
If a person uses names to contemplate, this is called verbal perfuming.
If a person leaves aside names, phrases, etc., and directly contemplates the meaning, this is called conceptual perfuming.
This manifests the subsequent two consciousnesses of the manifesting consciousness.
The two consciousnesses are:
The first is the four kinds of verbal consciousness, and the second is the consciousness of self and other distinctions, which manifest these two consciousnesses.
The remaining seven kinds of consciousness and discriminating consciousness, these eight kinds of consciousness arise from the perfuming of language.
There are also two kinds of consciousness:
The first is the body consciousness, and the second is the consciousness of the experiencer.
And the consciousness of self and other distinctions, these three consciousnesses arise from the perfuming of the view of self.
And the consciousness of good, evil, birth and death arises from the perfuming of the existence part.
These various consciousnesses are called the only consciousness that exists in the three realms. The third combined text and meaning of the subcommentary on the nine consciousnesses has two parts:
First, clarifying the essence of consciousness; second, clarifying the function of consciousness.
As for the essence of consciousness, it is presented in the Treatise on Consciousness Only.
The treatise says:
The only consciousness exists in the three realms.
Question:
All dharmas are just the three realms, why use two words?
Answer:
There are two meanings.
First, the divided is within the three realms, and the transformed is outside the realms. The four kinds of death are all. Second, the broad statement that all is.
What is meant by the ten directions?
The ten directions are not within the three realms, so it says all within the three realms.

Now, there is only consciousness. The above seven kinds of death are manifested by consciousness. Apart from consciousness, there is no separate substance, so it says within the three realms, there is only consciousness.
Realm means the meaning of self-nature.
Self-nature has two aspects:
First, the meaning of not being mixed. Desire is different from form, and form is not formless.

Second, the meaning of self-nature being unchanging and untransformable. Desire is desire, form is form, and the formless is formless. Good and evil are also like this. The three natures are unchanging.
There is only consciousness means that apart from consciousness, there is no separate object.
Because consciousness sees as if there were dust, apart from consciousness, dust has no substance.
The treatise says:
What is consciousness?
It refers to the three realms.
The commentary states:
Previously it was explained that without consciousness there are no three realms, and here it is explained that without the three realms there is no consciousness.
Moreover, the previous [verse] explains the function of the two consciousnesses.
The treatise states:
Consciousness is of two kinds: the manifesting consciousness and the discriminating consciousness.
The commentary states:
The first is the fundamental consciousness, which manifests the six sense objects.
The second is the six consciousnesses, which discriminate this from that.
Moreover, the former explains the perceived objects, while the latter explains the perceiving subjects.
Within the manifesting consciousness there are two kinds of transformations:
One transformation produces the six sense objects, and the other transformation produces the five sense faculties.
Next, the discriminating consciousness transforms into what resembles a self.
Thus the manas grasps the two consciousnesses and conceives of a self, which is the ÄdÄna and the mental consciousness jointly giving rise to the view of self.

The ÄdÄna consciousness grasps the fundamental consciousness and gives rise to the characteristics of the essence of the self, while the mental consciousness discriminates and conceives of the self having various distinct functions.
All dharmas are neither existent nor nonexistent. Because of the six sense objects, there are the six consciousnesses, so they cannot be definitely said to be nonexistent;

Apart from the six consciousnesses, there are no six sense objects, so they cannot be definitely said to exist.ğŸ”½Moreover, all dharmas cannot be definitely said to exist or definitely said to be nonexistent. The non-reality of the two kinds of self of persons and dharmas cannot be said to exist, and the true emptiness of the two kinds of self of persons and dharmas cannot be said to be nonexistent.

Moreover, all dharmas are definitely existent and definitely nonexistent. The two kinds of self of persons and dharmas are definitely nonexistent, and the emptiness of the two kinds of self of persons and dharmas is definitely existent.
These three together illustrate that the conventional is existent and the true is nonexistent.
Second, clarifying the function of consciousness.
The treatise says:
This discriminating consciousness, when it arises, establishes the power of perfuming in the Älaya consciousness.
The commentary says:
The power of perfuming is like burning incense perfuming a garment. The incense substance disappears but the fragrance still remains in the garment, called perfuming the garment.
This fragrance cannot be said to exist, because the incense substance has disappeared;
It cannot be said to be nonexistent, because the fragrance remains, and therefore it is called perfumation.
Just as when the six consciousnesses give rise to good and evil, they leave behind a perfuming force in the fundamental consciousness that can obtain future retribution, which is called a seed.
According to the HÄ«nayÄna interpretation, the PÅ«rvaÅ›aila school calls it non-loss, like a promissory note.
Therefore the Buddha spoke this verse:
Karmic actions are not lost, even after countless eons. When they accumulate,
they give rise to retribution for sentient beings.
The MahÄsÄá¹ƒghika school calls it grasping consciousness, which is a type of mental factor not directly associated with the mind.

It is like reciting a sÅ«tra. The first time through, one does not yet understand. The second recitation includes the first. In this way, up to the tenth recitation, when one has thoroughly mastered it, it includes the previous nine.

In the same way, the first consciousness can transform and remain in the first. In this way, up to the ninth transformation, which is included in the tenth. The tenth can include the previous nine. This tenth transformation is called grasping consciousness.
It has the previous nine uses, so it does not lose the previous nine.

The SarvÄstivÄda school is called obtaining according to attainment. Same means corresponding with number, place, time, etc. Long means not hindered by the three natures. Obtaining means not losing. Same also does not lose, and following also does not lose.

It is like the madhu flower, which is called the elm flower. Taking the juice of the lacquer tree, which is the red-colored juice, to dye the pistils of the madhu flower, the pistils and the red color are together. Later, when the fruit ripens, red color comes out. This is called simultaneous cultivation and attainment.
The red color reaches the fruit without being lost, so it is called same.
The red color that comes out before reaches the later, so it is called cultivation and attainment.

The red color reaches the fruit without being lost, so it is called same. The previous reaching of the later is not lost, so it is called following. Because the last manifestation is called attainment.
If it is the HetuvÄda school, it is called the consciousness with the possibility of existence.
Existence refers to the three existences, which are the three realms.
There are also seven existences:

The first is the intermediate existence, the second is the existence at birth, the third is the existence of action, and the fourth is the existence at death. Together with the previous three existences, there are seven existences.
The two realms of desire and form are endowed with four existences. If it is the formless realm, there is no intermediate existence.
The intermediate existence is correctly explained as heading towards the place of rebirth.
The place is called a place because there are causes and conditions.
Just as in the twelve links of dependent origination, because this thing exists, that thing exists; because this thing arises, that thing arises.
Existence is the cause. There are two kinds of causes:
The first is the prior cause, and the second is the simultaneous cause.
For example, the tangerine seed produces the sprout, which is the prior cause. When the sprout arises, it exists simultaneously with the tangerine.

The simultaneous cause, the condition of action producing consciousness, consciousness producing name-and-form, name-and-form producing the six sense bases, the six sense bases producing contact and feeling, etc., are simultaneous.
The reason for saying because this thing exists, that thing exists is to refute the non-Buddhist doctrine of the existence of birth.
The non-Buddhist doctrine states:
All sentient beings come from the self-existent God, therefore birth and death exist, the meaning of the internal statement is the same.
Now, it is refuted because it is produced by the previous cause, therefore it can be produced.
Your self-existent God does not exist, it is not born and does not give birth to birth and death, because this existence is born, therefore it cannot be existence.
Therefore it cannot be existence, therefore it is existence.

Therefore the Buddha establishes the principle that this thing exists, therefore it has birth. Your self-existent God exists, it is not born and does not give birth to birth and death, it is not the same as the internal meaning.
Up to being produced from the nature of the world, subtle dust, etc., it is also like this.
Moreover, the non-Buddhists establish that without a cause there is a result, the result is born naturally.
Therefore, to refute the non-Buddhists, this thing exists because it has a cause, therefore the matter of the result is this.
The reason for clarifying the two meanings is to clarify that because the conditions are complete, it can be produced.
If this thing exists, therefore this thing exists, this is the condition.
If this thing is born, therefore this thing is born, this clarifies the meaning of the cause.
The state of having parts refers to the place of rebirth, which is the cause and condition of rebirth.
This consciousness with parts is a retributive dharma, and it is definitely morally neutral by nature.
The four states of existence: from the stage of consciousness up to the age of six is the state of birth;
from the age of seven onward, being able to distinguish between what is ripe and unripe, giving rise to craving up until the moment of death, is the state of karma;
the state of death is a single moment of existence, which is the intermediate state.
Within the state of karma, the six consciousnesses give rise to three kinds of karma: good, bad, and unmoving karma.

The conditioned and the state of having parts are subsumed by the consciousness, and the six consciousnesses themselves perish, but by the power of being subsumed by the consciousness with parts, they remain.
Question:
Why establish the consciousness with parts?
Throughout one's lifetime, it always takes a single object as its object. If one is born in the heavens, this consciousness sees the rewards of pavilions and other things.
If the six consciousnesses arise, using coarse to cover and obstruct, then one is unaware of the function of this consciousness.
If one is born in an evil realm, this consciousness only takes fire carts, etc. as objects.
If the six consciousnesses of retribution are strong in function, then one is not aware of this consciousness taking objects.
If the six consciousnesses of the desire realm take objects of desire, ordinary beings cannot be aware of it, and so it is up to the formless realm.
If the various consciousnesses of the formless realm cease, then the function of this consciousness of existence becomes evident, like the store consciousness and the thinking consciousness.
As for seeds, this continuous transformation is able to attract future retribution, and this is called seeds.
Continuous without transformation is also not seeds; if only transformed without continuity, it is also not seeds.
Continuity and transformation are inseparable, and therefore seeds are formed.
Like the white color of a conch, it is neither the same nor different.
If the white color is the conch, then the conch has no three substances;
if the white color is different from the conch, then seeing the white color does not get the conch.
It cannot be said to be definitely different, because it is not different, it is called a white conch.
The transformation of the continuum is also like this, and thus it becomes the seed.
Due to the power of this perfuming, the fundamental consciousness will be able to arise in the future.
The commentary says:
If the power of the perfuming seeds is accomplished, the fundamental consciousness will be able to arise;
Due to the future manifestation of consciousness, the future discrimination of the six consciousnesses will be able to arise.
Therefore, samsara has no beginning or end.
If apart from afflictions, karma will not be able to arise.
If samsara has a beginning, then there would be a separate place for sentient beings in the beginning who give rise to afflictions and karma to experience the beginning place;
Since there are no sentient beings in the beginning giving rise to karma, there is no beginning to samsara, and thus we know that samsara has no beginning or end.
Four meanings clarify the absence of a beginning.
The first is not the original. If sentient beings initially had no later existence, this non-existence would not serve as the basis for existence. Existence has two kinds of faults:
First, if it does not exist, it cannot give rise to later existence. If it can give rise to existence, then it is not non-existence;
Second, the fault of equality. If something arises from space, then it could arise from non-existence.
Second, because one does not see sentient beings who are free from desire being born, there is no beginning to birth and death.
If there is no greed and so forth at the beginning of birth and death, and greed and so forth only appear later, then even those who are free from desire, such as arhats, should give rise to desire.
Because arhats do not give rise to desire again, we know that birth and death have no beginning.
Third, because the practice of pure conduct would be useless, birth and death have no beginning.

All sages cultivate the eightfold noble path in order to extinguish and prevent the arising of birth and death. Because those who are free from desire do not give rise to extinction again, we know that birth and death have no beginning.
Fourth, birth and death are of two kinds: one is the result of evil karma, the other is the good path.
This good and evil are due to the two causes of good and evil, and cannot be without a cause.
Is the beginning of this birth and death in the good path or the evil path?
If it is in the good path, then there is no good cause yet;ğŸ”½...
If it is an evil path, there is no evil cause yet.
Apart from the two paths of good and evil, there is no third path, so we know there is no beginning.
Objection:
The beginning is natural and does not depend on causes and conditions, while the latter depends on causes and conditions.
If so, this is unreasonable.
There are two faults:
First, it violates the principle of equality, and second, cause and effect are not similar.

If you say that samsara does not depend on causes and conditions, but the latter does, then it is not equal. Both the beginning and end are samsara, so why does one depend on causes and conditions and one not?

If you say that because there is no cause in the beginning, there should also be no cause in the end.
If there is no cause in the beginning but a cause in the end, then it cannot give rise to anything.
If it can give rise to something, beans should give rise to barley, and barley should also give rise to beans.
Since this is not the case, we know that what you previously said about the subsequent effect being produced by the previous cause is not correct.

The Buddha spoke a verse, the first line of which shows that consciousness is precisely the Älaya, and the Älaya is the consciousness of karmic retribution, while discriminating consciousness is the consciousness of afflictions.
This arises from the consciousness of karmic retribution and gives rise to the consciousness of afflictions, and the consciousness of afflictions is precisely the ÄdÄna consciousness and so forth.

The next line clarifies that from afflictions consciousness arises, and from consciousness perfuming arises. Perfuming is precisely the function of karma, which can transform the fundamental consciousness into the consciousness of seeds.
The next line is from karma karmic retribution arises.
The next line concludes the cycle of birth and death.
The cycle means that because it is indeterminate, sometimes the cause transforms into the effect, and sometimes the effect transforms into the cause.
As for the statement that perfuming has two kinds, it is to illustrate two meanings:

First, it illustrates the expedient means for birth and death, which is called deviant and also called contrary. Second, it illustrates the expedient means for nirvÄá¹‡a, which is called correct and also called in accordance.
Those who cling to the imagined nature, all dharmas have three natures:
one is the imagined nature, two is the dependent nature, three is the true reality nature.
The imagined nature is the dharmas manifested by names and expressions.
The dependent nature is all dharmas manifested by the principle of cause and effect.
The true reality nature is the suchness nature of all dharmas.ğŸ”½Imagination has the nature of signlessness.
The dependent has the nature of non-arising.
What is called nature has five meanings:
First, the meaning of self-nature and type. All pots, clothes, etc. are not apart from the type of the four elements. The same is the nature of the four elements. This is the meaning of self-nature.

Second, the meaning of causal nature. All the principles of the four foundations of mindfulness are the principles that are the objects of the holy Dharma. Relying on these principles can give rise to the holy Dharma. This is also the meaning of cause.
Third, the meaning of arising. If a thing has no arising, its nature cannot be seen. Since the meaning of arising can be seen, nature is explained as arising.
The five-part Dharma body is the meaning of the arising nature.
The TathÄgata's correct teachings give rise to three kinds of faith in sentient beings who have faith and delight:

First, faith in the existence of true principles; second, faith in attaining the merits of the five-part Dharma body; third, perfecting the cultivation of the five-part body for one's own benefit and the benefit of others.
Since the arising of the five-part body manifests the attainment of nature, therefore the five-part Dharma body arises and takes this as its meaning.
Fourth, the meaning of indestructibility. This nature is not defiled in ordinary beings and is not purified in sages, thus it is called indestructible.
Fifth, the meaning of the secret treasury. Approaching it purifies one's conduct, while going against it leads to distancing oneself.
This Dharma is difficult to attain and hidden, thus it is called secret, which is also the meaning of treasury.
There are four kinds of arising:
First, arising from contact, like a child born from the union of a man and woman.
Second, birth from smell, like cattle, sheep, and so on. When males and females have lustful thoughts, the male smells the female's orifices and then has offspring.
Third, birth from sand, like chickens, sparrows, and so on. When female sparrows have lustful thoughts, they sprinkle their bodies with dust and sand, and then lay eggs and give birth to chicks.
Fourth, birth from sound, like cranes, peacocks, and so on. When they have lustful thoughts, they hear the male's calls and lay eggs to give birth to chicks.
All birds that hatch from eggs are inedible and have offspring.
The discriminated nature is emptiness of non-existence, because the discriminated dharma cannot be obtained.
The dependent nature is emptiness of non-suchness, which is the refutation of the grasped.
The true nature is emptiness of self-nature, because there are no two selves of person and dharma, which is the emptiness of self-nature.
Furthermore, the discriminated nature is like a flower in the sky, which is utterly non-existent.

The dependent nature is different from a flower in the sky, resembling an illusion, not empty or existent. By contemplating the dependent nature as neither existent nor non-existent, one can attain the path and become a sage.
Emptiness and nonexistence are annihilation. Contemplating emptiness and nonexistence cannot attain the Way and accomplish sagehood.
All afflictions and separate attachments are the nature of discrimination, and all dharmas are the nature of reality that one desires to contemplate and cultivate.
Attachment and contemplation belong to the nature of dependent arising.
These two kinds of dharmas are called perfuming:
one is the perfuming of the seeds of afflictions, and the other is the perfuming of the seeds of the path.
The second perfuming increases the fundamental consciousness because they are of the same kind.
The fundamental consciousness takes suchness as its object and gives rise to the four kinds of slander, which is false perfuming.
The seeds and afflictions are both false, and therefore perfuming can increase the fundamental consciousness.
It is like how sweet things can increase blandness, and blandness is also the nature of sweetness, so it can increase because of the same nature.
As for being endowed with all abilities, it clarifies that karma has four kinds:

First, one may commit but not increase, like a sharp-witted person who encounters an evil friend and gives rise to unwholesome karma, which is committing. But because they immediately regret it, they do not increase.

Second, one may increase but not commit, like a person who is ashamed and follows others in practicing, this good is increased and expanded, but they are unable to give rise to it themselves, so they do not commit.
Third, one may both commit and increase, like a person who creates wholesome karma and constantly cultivates it, this wholesome karma is expanded and greatly increased.
Fourth, one may neither commit nor increase, which is the uncontaminated wholesome karma.
If it is increased and expands the retribution of saá¹ƒsÄra, it is called committing. Uncontaminated [karma] can eliminate saá¹ƒsÄra, so it does not increase.
The first three are karma, and the latter part is not.
Among the first three, take the third statement, which is both committing and increasing, so it says fully endowed with all dharmas.
That which can give rise to the six destinies is able to obtain the fruits of birth and death in the six destinies, and gives rise to the causes of the Älaya consciousness.

The expedient of perfuming the causes for the completion of this birth and death body causes birth and death to be accomplished, therefore it is said that this cause means the completion of birth and death.

The second contemplation is the contemplation of the true nature of habitual tendencies. Contemplating the three kinds of natures is called the contemplation of the true nature of habitual tendencies.
Contemplation has four functions:
First, the contemplation of elimination, second, the contemplation of cessation, third, the contemplation of realization, and fourth, the contemplation of cultivation.
Contemplating suchness is the nature of the truth of suffering, and the three truths are also like this.

Contemplating suchness and the four truths has four functions. Contemplating suchness and the cessation of suffering and the cessation of accumulation is contemplating suchness and realizing cessation. Uniting with suchness is cultivating the path.

It can eliminate the attachment to the nature of discrimination. Discrimination makes existence out of nonexistence. The true contemplation reveals existence and nonexistence to be contrary to self-nature, therefore it is called elimination.
The nature of discrimination is the first habitual tendency that is damaged. The present is damaged and the future is destroyed.
If the truth of accumulation is damaged, suffering is also damaged.
As for the Älaya consciousness being damaged, the originally existing seven layers of the truth of suffering in the three realms are divided into three layers.

After the three layers are damaged, the Älaya consciousness is the basis for receiving retribution. Although there are no afflictions and karma that attract it, it no longer enters the three realms to be born, but receives birth within the four kinds of birth and death in the untainted realm, and so on, until there is no more state of birth and death.
Because the Älaya is damaged, the receiving of birth is also damaged.
Why is this?
It shows that consciousness is discriminating consciousness. Because the Älaya consciousness is damaged, it is known that discriminating consciousness is also damaged.
This consciousness of the individual self and the six sense objects and so on has already been completely extinguished, not just damaged.
The present mention of being damaged is based on the pure aspect of speech.
This is together with the fundamental consciousness being completely exhausted. This Älaya consciousness that can be eliminated is to be eradicated.
